question.title: caching a serialized immutable object in Jackson
question.body:
Use case

Say I have an HTTP endpoint that constructs an immutable object then sends that immutable object to multiple sinks. Maybe I send it to a couple of message brokers, other HTTP endpoints, a file, whatever.

On each send, let's say Jackson is being used to serialize the immutable object.

Questions

Am I right that I could get a significant performance benefit if Jackson could

  1. recognize (or be told) that the object was immutable and was going to serialized multiple times
  2. cache the result of the first serialization in a byte-sequence of some kind
  3. reuse that byte-sequence on subsequent calls to write...

If there would be a benefit, my second question is: does Jackson or any other popular serialization framework offer this optimization?

Thoughts

If that is a benefit to performance, it would really be nice if the serialization framework offered it. While I could write my own wrapper and memoize the result, I would then lose the type-safety of the calls to the sending functions.

I guess it would still be tricky because each of the sending functions would need to be using the same ObjectMapper (or the same cache, at least).

question_comments.body: Probably not worth it, as Jorge Campos wrote; my only addition would be, why don't you try a little benchmark to measure the actual time it takes Jackson to serialize the object? And how many bytes is the serialized form?

If you have a large object, than it is worth it. If you know that you only use JSON for example, then you can store the serialized value at the object creation, under a transient field. Then use a method, for example serialized to retrieve the value. Yoiu will not use the automatic transformation on the message brokers or endpoints, you would send them the byte array.

IMHO it is just not worth it. Exactly because of this: "I guess it would still be tricky because each of the sending functions would need to be using the same ObjectMapper (or the same cache, at least)." not to mention you are adding more complexity that might need to be handled: between serialize, >>> add to cache <<<, receiver: gets message, >>> check on cache <<<. Serialization/deserialization on todays world is super fast unless you have really huge complex objects floating around and that in itself would also not be recommended in general
